reviewText:
PROS: Amazing concept, the game also look very polished. The story is there to introduce you to the basics, and is a mix between 1984 and The Matrix.

MID: The fact that you can complete the actual story under 2 hours without tryharding isn't really what bothers me. Endless mode and challenges are here to keep you entertained, plus the game got tons of secret and hidden content.
The price tag ? It was the same when I bought it in beta, over a year ago. Would I buy it now, at this price, for this content, if I haden't before ? Probably not. On sale would be better.

CONS: Poorly optimized. The beta already suffered from this, but I can't believe the game still manages to stutter so much. Frame drops, freezes, specially shapes-filled situations. Moreover, all of this still happens on lowest settings, and on a high-end gaming PC.

Overall, the game is great, the concept is great, but as of right now it needs some love and some testing in order to be really great, so i wouldn't recommend buying it at full price.

1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

reviewText:
Not worth the asking price.

What I played was promising but I was pretty let down.

I agree that the time stopping mechanic is both cool and fun, but the mere five weapons and one enemy type really doesn't cut it for me, particularly with the short length of the game and asking price of $35(!) Canadian.

The lack of a soundtrack is a stylistic choice, but not one I agree with. I feel like having music that was slowed down with the time stops would have added to the experience.


It's not unenjoyable, but it feels like you're paying a whole lot of money for an early access game that isn't going to get finished. You could do worse with your money than SUPERHOT but it really could have been more.

reviewText:
Fantastically polished game, SUPERHOT takes the prototype and does an excellent job of developing the mechanics in to a finalised product that's worth every penny.

SUPERHOT has a very simple ruleset, and equally simple (but effective) visuals to accommodate that. As a result it's always very clear what you're supposed to be doing. While it is an FPS game, the core mechanic turns it in to something much more strategy-based, especially when attempting the challenge modes.

The main criticism people have with the game is that it's too short, and that's true if you ignore all the extra content that comes after completing the story mode. If you're somebody that enjoys challenging yourself, then you'll have many hours of fun with the challenge modes, in that respect the story mode is more like a long tutorial.

My only personal gripe is that the boss character featured in the prototype didn't make an appearance, but understandably they decided to take the game in a different direction.

In short, if you like the look of this and you understand that the story mode is only a small portion of the game, then I absolutely recommend it.

reviewText:
It's fun and fresh but plays more like a tech demo of sorts. I'm not even going to complain about the pricing, frankly the game is not fleshed out enough to justify a purchase at all. Even on a sale. You'll play the single player, maybe dabble in some of the challenge or endless modes and then you'll realize you won't really want to play it anymore.

If you're really interested, buy it, play it for under 2 hours and return. It's definitely worth trying but don't let the cheap meta story hook you into playing past the return time limit. There's a vague, tacked on narrative here that really feels like it's in place to take advantage of your curiousity so that you'll think there's something worth playing towards but there really isn't. Nothing satisfying at least and by that point it'll probably be past the point of steam returns, so don't fall for that trap.

There's likely some community based ARG that helps unveil THE TRUE STORY" but I don't know. I guess if you're into that then this is for you. To me it just seems like they're deceiving customers into being okay with any kind of quality gameplay running dry after only a couple hours.

Tl;dr
It's original
date: so it'll feel fun at first
recommended: but you'll very quickly realize it's shallow and boring."

reviewText:
While I agree that $25 is a steep asking price for SUPERHOT, to complain that it's only two hours long is misguided.
If you take the time to look at my playtime, you'll see why I disagree.
If you sprint through SUPERHOT doing everything the most practical way you can, you'll have a boring two hours.
If you spend your time in SUPERHOT doing awesome-looking, suicidal, absurd trickshots in slow-motion, you'll come to enjoy what is some of the best gameplay I have ever experienced, by far.
I wish it was something closer to $15, but SUPERHOT is approaching perfection regardless.

You have to check out this game. It's the most innovative shooter I've played in years.""

reviewText:
This game is great.  What a breath of fresh air.  The base gameplay feels like nothing else I've ever played.  This is action that has all kinds of craziness to it at a pace that is slowed down a little bit more than enough to barely be able to deal with it all.  Time only moves when you do, but you're still under constant pressure and constant fire.  Throwing guns at people to take their other guns from them, dodging bullets, grabbing a telephone and whipping it at the incoming bullets to destroy that oncoming shotgun blast, switching bodies to the guy behind the machine gunner giving you trouble and punching him in the head, etc etc etc..

The campaign is great, but it's just the warm-up.  Once it is completed there are Endless modes and Challenges to complete and unlock.  The first to unlock is a Katana-Only set of what you already know, but you're unable to use anything but the Katana you started with.  Switches up every strategy I had formed prior.  I found myself learning new tricks the whole way.  My friends and I have been switching off every couple runs in an attempt to unlock everything and even after 13 hours we still haven't unlocked it all yet.

There's a couple minigames hiding in here, like Tree Dude, which can be fun if you're in the mood for something simple.

I don't think the price is too high, and I don't think the campaign is too short (since it's really just at tutorial, sort of).  This the most innovative shooter I've played in years!

reviewText:
IT'S THE MOST INNOVATIVE SHOOTER I'VE PLAYED IN YEARS
Now that I've gotten that obligation out of the way, SUPERHOT is a short but sweet game centered around the premise of time manipulation in a first-person shooter. If you haven't played the free demo that's been floating around online for the last couple years, you should probably play it, as that will determine whether or not you'll like this game.

There's an overall narrative similar to Pony Island, if you've played it. Basically, you're thrown from stage to stage with the objective of killing all the red guys. They'll be equipped with their fists, pistols, shotguns, machine guns, etc... And you'll be using time manipulation to deal with all of them. They take one hit (3 with fists or thrown objects) to kill, and so do you. If you die at any point during one of the many brief stages, you'll be thrown back to the beginning of that stage to learn from your mistakes, and try again, eventually defeating all of your foes, and moving onto the next stage.

The main story mission takes about 90 minutes to complete, give or take a little based on your ability to grasp the time manipulation concept.

Once you're finished with the main story mission, you'll be provided with access to all 32 missions you previously completed, endless mode, and some challenges.

Endless mode is a whole bunch of levels from the story mode where the overall goal in each level is to kill as many enemies as you possibly can, allowing you to unlock even more levels in this mode. This is probably the mode that most of your money is going toward, as it seems to provide the most content out of anything in the game. So before somebody tries to persuade you that the game is too expensive for a 2 hour (or 90 minute in my case) campaign, they probably didn't try out endless mode.

Challenges are unlocked by accomplishing certain tasks throughout the story mode's missions, and once a challenge is unlocked, it will unlock a new mode for all of the main story missions, such as a speed run mode, or a speed run mode with a timer that counts down even when you're not moving. Not quite sure what all the other modes are, as I haven't unlocked them yet. There's 13 in total. Besides the two speedrun ones I have, there's also one where you only have a katana.

Beyond the main time manipulation game, you can also navigate the game's unique main menu to find some other various mini-games and fun bonus content.

I've seen the pricing for this game compared to something like Firewatch, but in the end, both games are around the same length, except Firewatch doesn't have any endgame content, and frankly SUPERHOT's story is more interesting.

Pros    Unique time manipulation mechanic for an FPS.
Unique graphics, combined with interesting UI that makes for an interesting narrative similar to Pony Island.
A lot more bang for your buck that I would have initially expected based on the demo that released however many years ago.
Dodging enemy bullets can get really fun, especially when you realize that they tend to lead their shots, so strafing in one direction is generally not the best decision.
Neat mechanic introduced late into the game that I'd rather not spoil here. It's used in endless mode though. Really cool feature in the game that I wasn't expecting.
The story mission levels are based around action scenes in popular films.
When you finish a level in any mode, you get to watch and edit the full-speed version of the entire level's gameplay footage from your perspective. That means none of the time manipulation stops, so you get to look like you're even better at first-person shooters than you really are. Clips can be edited and uploaded straight to a website called Killstagram too.
SUPERHOT SUPERHOT SUPERHOT
Cons    For a game that touts an endless mode based around high scores, there's no online leaderboards, at least at launch that is. I have no idea if the devs plan on adding them in post-launch or something, but as it is, you kill as many baddies as possible in a level, and then when you die, it saves that score, and you can view it from the level select screen as your Personal High Score". Kind of makes trying to achieve high scores not as much of a thrill when you're competing with yourself.
Endless mode levels are also unlocked based on overall kills in that level

reviewText:
SUPERHOT is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing bonkers. SUPERHOT would be a Jackie Chan movie, if Jackie Chan was really into cyberpunk and had seen The Matrix a thousand times. It's a game where you beat up a dude in a bathroom stall, then you pick up the bottle in the corner of the restroom, use it to glass the face of the red dude coming in for a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and after all that, you see the bartender with his shotgun in his hands, and you dare to pick up one of the billard balls on the pool table, and then you dare even harder to chuck it at his ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing head. It's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing wonderful improvisation combat in the form of a puzzle FPS.

The game does a fantastic job telling you all the basics without having to explain it to you through its use of colors and visual language. The scenery is white-grey, things you kill with are colored black, red dudes are bad and must be punished, use black things to kill red dudes. Even if you haven't played many FPS games, you'll know instantly what's going on, allowing you to focus on the puzzle side of the game - the puzzle of how you kill those red dudes. And even then, the game manages to pull out some novel takes on its formula - the Elevator Pitch level is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing great take on using your fists to get the upper hand on three people with guns pointed at you point-blank.

Some whiners say that the three-hour campaign is too little story for $25. But they're also ignoring the wealth of challenges, the Endless mode, and the various secrets built into the game. And even if we're judging the game entirely by its entire campaign - SUPERHOT has a really well done, solid campaign, one that hits its mark, never misses a beat, and knows exactly where to start and when to quit. I'd rather have a campaign that is three hours long, artfully paced, knowing how best to deliver its thrills, and is concluded properly rather than a campaign that takes fifteen hours, wears out its welcome, and farts out a conclusion that makes me never want to play the game again after I'm done. Have we learned nothing from ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing Portal, a game that is almost flawless and just two hours long? Meeting an arbitrary goal of how much time your game consumes does not make a game good.

The only real complaint I have is that I don't know if the stuff between the campaign levels is going to hold up for me down the line? I imagine myself old and toothless, and I'll scream WHAT IS THIS DOS ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, I NEED TO KILL THE RED PEOPLE. And then I'll throw my cellphone at the TV and have to be sent to work in the salt mines on the Plutonian Asteroid and Old Folks' Home. Being old is going to suck, but at least I'll always have Superhot!

reviewText:
The basic premise is a friend of yours finds a crack to a new video game and sends it to your computer.
I guess I could define it as a time based, first person shooter...
But, that wouldn't be exactly correct.
I could say it's a puzzle game disguised as a shooter, but that would leave out the time dilation, hacking, amazing ballistics simulation, and of course... things... things I can't tell you.
SuperHot is something that has to be experienced first hand.
What you see and do is not going to be the same as you would think you would do.
The cool thing about SuperHot is you don't realize there is a deeper story unless you dig for it.
Yes SuperHot has shooting, it has time based movement,
it has puzzles, semi-hacking and unique graphics that are freaky mixture of ASCII text and modern-gen effects.
SuperHot can be brutally difficult at times as well.
Other times, it can seem to easy. Once you learn the best way to attack, some weapons can feel too overpowered while others are pretty worthless.
The AI will run you down and will fire off that fatal shot just one micro-second before you were going to blast that red dude down with some buckshot.
In fairness I can not fully review this game, because doing so would give too much of the experience away.
If you like shooters mixed with cool retro vibe and some conspiracy theory mixed in, SuperHot should be right up your alley.
The game is very polished, runs great and is a pleasure to play.
This is a thinking person's game though.
Don't expect to charge head on to the enemy blasting away. You have to pick your moments of attack, all the while keeping your head on a 360 degree swivel for that sneaky ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that will come up behind you.
Usually if you hear a gunshot from a new direction that you are unaware of, you are already dead. The difficulty is fair as can be though. Nothing happens in the world until you move.
Bad guy standing right in front of you with a machine gun?
He will not move or fire an inch until you do (Well, he will but very, very slowly).
This gives you tactical time to think of the best course of action.
Moving quickly will only get you killed faster. Take your time and think out your options. Sometimes the best option is a punch to the face.
Here is an example of a level:
I start out with no weapons. A man is in front of me with a baseball bat. He is very, very slowly running toward me.
I wait until he is in reach and punch him. As he is knocked back I grab the baseball bat that gets thrown from his grip.
Spinning around I see another guy with his bat halfway through the arc to bash in my brains, I gut him with my bat and continue spinning around to the first guy who is starting to recover from my punch.
I smash him in the head and move forward.
Now I see a guy coming down a hallway with a pistol. He runs toward me as I dart between pillars. When he comes around the corner to shoot at me I smash his hand with my bat and grab his gun from the air while tossing my bat at his face.
I spin around again and pop a shot into the knees of the other bat boy who was right behind me. I hear a boom and see red tracers flying through the air at the spot I was just 1 second ago.
Another unseen doorway had opened with another guy with a shotgun. I raise my gun up and fire off a round but by the time the bullet reaches him he has already moved in another direction.
Got him now... click... click... click. No!, my gun is empty!
He is only 4 feet from me now and is raising the shotgun up to eye level.
I panic and throw the pistol at him.
The pistol hits him just as he fires.
The bullets from his shotgun are too close for me to dodge and I go down at the same time screaming NOOOOOO!
SUPERHOT!
If that doesn't get your blood pumping, then you need to have your pulse checked.

SuperHot - 7 out of 10 Total

Graphics:	8 / 10
Graphically this game looks good for what it is.
There are basically three colors in the world.
White, Red and Black. However, the way the graphics are presented
and the smooth framerate more than make up for more realistic looking graphics.

Gameplay:	  7.5 / 10
Gunplay is pretty solid, other than the annoyance of waiting for the next bullet in the clip to be ready (my biggest gaming gripe about this game), but I see why they did it from a gameplay point of view. Katanas feel especially powerful, with being able to cut a guy in half with one swipe and even chop bullets in half mid-flight.

Story:  7 / 10
The story as such starts out typical of a guy being excited for a new game and slowly ratchets up to something unexpected and different. While not the most engaging story (not any character development, drama or comedy), this story is all about mystery and excitement and does a fine job with just that.

Audio:  8 / 10
Does the job. Nothing amazing but no problems either.

PC Options:  6 / 10
No real options other than default stuff like resolution, Windowed mode and 2 or 3 small things. Would have liked to see some neat features like different color shaders and the like.

Price:  6 / 10
The price at release is the biggest problem I have.
The game is good. The game does what it says on the tin.
However, the lack of variety of gameplay and rather short story mode really bring this score down. If it was $15 rather than $25 I would have no issues with the price.

Final Word:
While SuperHot's main story mode is rather short,  it makes up for it with extra modes like Endless Mode and Challenges that open up after the main game finishes. If you are looking for an interesting take on a bad guy vs good guy shooter without a lot of dialogue or missions, other than to kill the red guys, then SuperHot might be worth checking out.
If you can wait for a sale, I would wait for the $15 to $20 price point. If you follow my twitter @jdwohlever message me and I'll send you a coupon code for 15% off while supplies last.

reviewText:
In SUPERHOT, you control time! It's more of puzzle game than a FPS though because you need to have patience to plan your movements. If you rush in, you will likely die. When you stop moving, time nearly haults as well. You can use this time manipulation to dodge bullets, narrowly avoiding death as you destroy all of the enemies in each level. Throw weapons or various objects to block bullets and disarm your enemies, hot switch to change places with one of your enemies, leaving them to die instead of you.

Please check out my Quick Review Video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ViYBuzR0ac
Pros:
-interesting and intriguing story (it took me about 3.5 hours for the main story)
-awesome, fun, and unique gameplay
-lots of content after the main story (different challenges, time trials, endless modes)
-easy to upload and share your replays to Superhot's killstagram.com right in the game

Cons:
-not a whole lot of menu options (lacks fullscreen windows, controls)
-SUPER HOT repeating voice gets annoying after each level

Overall, the story was well done, and the gameplay was very enjoyable. This game has a lot to offer, and you can pull off some really crazy plays. If you enjoy challenge modes, timed modes, and/or endless modes, this game is certainly worth the full price. However, if you intend to play ONLY the main story, I suggest waiting for a sale.

reviewText:
The most innovative shooter I've played in years. Seriously.

Pros:
- Unique and incredible gameplay.
- Challenging levels.
- Beautiful graphics, sound and art style.
- Endless mode.

Cons:
- Story a little short.
- A bit too highly priced?

I was one of those people who played the original demo of SUPERHOT when it was a browser game. I loved it and so could not wait to get my hands on a copy when I saw it had been released on Steam, really hoping that it would have the same thrill that it gave me all those years ago.

Oh boy, did it do just that.

SUPERHOT really offers something I've not seen in many other games. I think the thing that shines most from it is the unique gameplay, and how you not only have to think about your movement but also which weapon is suited best at the current time.

As for the story, although a little confusing, I did question what it was really about and after completing the game I am fairly sure that was its intention. I won't reveal much about it as you really have to experience it for yourself and ask your own questions (also the game asks for no reveals).

The graphics, sound and art style are all fantastic and will keep you zoned into the game for hours.

On the down side however, I would have liked the story to be a little longer especially for that asking price. On the plus side though the completition of it unlocks the 'Endless Mode' plus challenges, extending the gameplay.

There are also a few minor bugs, the most notable I found was bullets hitting walls where there were no walls.

That's my view of it, but I highly recommend you check it out for yourself or even just the browser demo if you're not sure. Overall a very stunning game and easily one of my favourites to play.

CONS:

reviewText:
Fantastic game based on an incredible concept, made by a team that clearly has a lot of passion for their work. Backed this on kickstarter a long time ago, and got access to the beta a few weeks ago and have had a absolute blast in both the campaign mode, and the endless survival mode.

While the game itself is incredibly fun, and the reason alone for me playing and enjoying the game so much, I think it could benefit from more weapon and enemy diversity, and certainly from the addition of a level editor. The levels included are already very simple, but well-thought out, and I think allowing players to make their own, and really harness the true potential of the Matrix-esque gameplay would add a lot to the long-term replayeability.

PROS:
+ Great art style and sound design
+ Very satisfying core gameplay loop
+ Great level design
+ Good level diversity
+ Great replayeability w/ challenges and Endless mode

CONS:
- No level editor
- ~2 Hour campaign
- Limited enemy and weapon variety

EDIT: It's the most innovative shooter I've played in years

reviewText:
Stylish as all hell and plays like a puzzle game with guns due to its core mechanic. Is it worth $25? I'm compelled to say no, but only as a general recommendation. Most people probably won't get $25 out of the game, but some people definitely will.

I put a lot of hours into just the proof of concept they put out forever ago, which speaks to the replayability inherent in its design: while linear overall, the spaces you're given to work in have a lot of nooks and crannies and there are often many ways to approach a level. Since you're navigating these small spaces in fractions of realtime, even the smallest bits of cover can become huge boons to you and the smallest bits of bare corridor can become deathtraps.

In this full version, there are a now bevy of modifiers and cheats that you can add in while replaying levels to spice things up, a score attack/survival mode and other nifty little extras to keep you coming back. If you're the type of person who enjoys exploiting novel mechanics, experimenting and seeing how far you can push your luck, it may be a $25 game. For people interested in the concept but not of the type to replay things over and over, I'd say $10 is the sweet spot.

Also, go play the free prototype on their website if you're unsure about the game. (Requires the Unity web plugin, so if you use Chrome, you'll have to switch to something else to play, as they cut NPAPI support a while back.) The core gameplay is almost indistinguishable from the final product and it's a hell of a lot of fun. I'm tempted to say you'll want to give these guys money just to encourage them to keep developing new concepts into the future.

reviewText:
Not much to the overly vague story in this game but that hardly matters. SUPERHOT has some of the most unique gameplay I've ever experienced in a shooter. Here's a quick rundown.

- Goal is to kill everyone
- Time moves at normal rate when you move, dramatically slows down when you're standing still
- Gun-to-gun gampeplay, similar to Hotline Miami but in 3D space
- Bullets travel at a dodgeable speed for both you and your enemies, makes leading difficult and rewarding
- Ability to swap bodies, which allows you to evade foreseeable death or just use a body swap to kill an enemy
- Multitude of guns/melee weapons (pistol, AR, shotgun, katana, household objects, etc)

Price tag is a tad steep for the amount of content you get.

I still definitely recommend it though.

***I RECOMMEND THE GAME BUT NOT AT $25***

SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT.

I still don't have a clue what that means but in the 1.5 hours of my time with the game, I can already tell you to save your money. It is without a doubt an innovative and addicting game but and I say but, I can't tell you to get a game for this price just to only play with it for a few hours. It is a really fun shooter that makes you think instead of act like in most shooters. TotalBiscuit did a good job comparing the game to puzzle games which is exactly what I think SUPERHOT has done. I'd consider this game to be a great indie title that I'd buy for around $15 but not $25. Wait for a 40% off sale on Steam (This upcoming summer) and buy it then.

reviewText:
The most innovative shooter I've played in years. Seriously.

Pros:
- Unique and incredible gameplay.
- Challenging levels.
- Beautiful graphics, sound and art style.
- Endless mode.

Cons:
- Story a little short.
- A bit too highly priced?

I was one of those people who played the original demo of SUPERHOT when it was a browser game. I loved it and so could not wait to get my hands on a copy when I saw it had been released on Steam, really hoping that it would have the same thrill that it gave me all those years ago.

Oh boy, did it do just that.

SUPERHOT really offers something I've not seen in many other games. I think the thing that shines most from it is the unique gameplay, and how you not only have to think about your movement but also which weapon is suited best at the current time.

As for the story, although a little confusing, I did question what it was really about and after completing the game I am fairly sure that was its intention. I won't reveal much about it as you really have to experience it for yourself and ask your own questions (also the game asks for no reveals).

The graphics, sound and art style are all fantastic and will keep you zoned into the game for hours.

On the down side however, I would have liked the story to be a little longer especially for that asking price. On the plus side though the completition of it unlocks the 'Endless Mode' plus challenges, extending the gameplay.

There are also a few minor bugs, the most notable I found was bullets hitting walls where there were no walls.

That's my view of it, but I highly recommend you check it out for yourself or even just the browser demo if you're not sure. Overall a very stunning game and easily one of my favourites to play.

reviewText:
Fantastic game based on an incredible concept, made by a team that clearly has a lot of passion for their work. Backed this on kickstarter a long time ago, and got access to the beta a few weeks ago and have had a absolute blast in both the campaign mode, and the endless survival mode.

While the game itself is incredibly fun, and the reason alone for me playing and enjoying the game so much, I think it could benefit from more weapon and enemy diversity, and certainly from the addition of a level editor. The levels included are already very simple, but well-thought out, and I think allowing players to make their own, and really harness the true potential of the Matrix-esque gameplay would add a lot to the long-term replayeability.

PROS:
+ Great art style and sound design
+ Very satisfying core gameplay loop
+ Great level design
+ Good level diversity
+ Great replayeability w/ challenges and Endless mode

CONS:
- No level editor
- ~2 Hour campaign
- Limited enemy and weapon variety

EDIT: It's the most innovative shooter I've played in years

reviewText:
Mr Anderson,you may have defeated the Matrix,but you will never destroy it.Now,you are invading our home and we will do what it takes to get you out of our system....or even worse.

This game is a breath of fresh air compared to all them new games that keep the same fast-paced gameplay.
In SUPERHOT you can take a break while the guy tries to shoot you and think of a way to kill him while time is going really,really slow.

I have heard about this game ever since it was still a prototype back in 2014,but the creators made this game after they participated in the 7 Day FPS Challenge.

Now,here are a few points on why you should buy the game:
-Awesome story(not gonna give spoilers,but its a pretty short story)
-Endless badass gameplay
-Challenge mode.Can you beat the game with speciffic conditions like only melee or death timer?
-The original experience(this one can be understood by the players who knew way back when about this game.basically,u play the same levels,but with the graphics of the 2013 version of the game and its limitaions,meaning u can only pick up guns but u can one punch the enemy).
-Free updates.All the contents that will be realeased in the future will be totally free for the person who bought the game.

Now here are a few downpoints about this game:
-Too expensive.Although it has an endless mode and an challenge mode,I don't think its worth to pay this much especially since the story is really short and the modes only repeat the same levels with different challenges.(those who preordered it had to pay only 14 dollars through paypal)
-Repetitive.Although you might think it would be awesome to play the same level with different challenges,its still the same level.

My opinion?
Well,it really depends on you and you only if you want this game or not.I recommend it to those who really know what they are getting for their money.Maybe in the future people will be able to make their own levels and have like a leaderboard to be even more competitive.I'm not saying is a bad game when it comes to anything.It's just that after some time you will get bored of just reapeating the same level over and over again just for some achievement.
But if you really want this game,it will be a good time and can always make you feel like a badass when you ninja jump on someone with a katana.

reviewText:
SUPERHOT IS THE MOST INNOVATIVE SHOOTER I'VE PLAYED IN YEARS!

In all seriousness, SUPERHOT really is a fresh take on shooters, it is great for people who can appreciate a game for it's enjoyable mechanics and gameplay, and don't need a fully fledged story and GPU taxing graphics (although the story/lore is spread throughout the whole game, including secrets, minigames and the likes, and the purposely simplistic look is still quite aesthetically pleasing).

You don't beat the game when you're finished with story mode, it's more of an primer to the arena and challenge modes, the latter of which take the story levels for a spin and introduce new features and limitations, forcing you to change up your playstyle. The Endless aka the arena mode is just killing red guys. As many as possible. With constantly spawning reinforcements.

This game is obviously not for everybody, whether you'll enjoy the experience or not will depend on your expectations and attitude towards it, if you like games like Hotline Miami, and/or are a completionist, SUPERHOT is definitely a good pick for you. And if your satisfaction of hitting insane shots, slicing through dudes with a katana and watching the real time replays of your slow motion killing sprees barely drops after thousands of kills, you'll know you have received the signal.

reviewText:
Not much to the overly vague story in this game but that hardly matters. SUPERHOT has some of the most unique gameplay I've ever experienced in a shooter. Here's a quick rundown.

- Goal is to kill everyone
- Time moves at normal rate when you move, dramatically slows down when you're standing still
- Gun-to-gun gampeplay, similar to Hotline Miami but in 3D space
- Bullets travel at a dodgeable speed for both you and your enemies, makes leading difficult and rewarding
- Ability to swap bodies, which allows you to evade foreseeable death or just use a body swap to kill an enemy
- Multitude of guns/melee weapons (pistol, AR, shotgun, katana, household objects, etc)

Price tag is a tad steep for the amount of content you get.

I still definitely recommend it though.

reviewText:
SUPERHOT IS THE MOST INNOVATIVE SHOOTER I'VE PLAYED IN YEARS!

In all seriousness, SUPERHOT really is a fresh take on shooters, it is great for people who can appreciate a game for it's enjoyable mechanics and gameplay, and don't need a fully fledged story and GPU taxing graphics (although the story/lore is spread throughout the whole game, including secrets, minigames and the likes, and the purposely simplistic look is still quite aesthetically pleasing).

You don't beat the game when you're finished with story mode, it's more of an primer to the arena and challenge modes, the latter of which take the story levels for a spin and introduce new features and limitations, forcing you to change up your playstyle. The Endless aka the arena mode is just killing red guys. As many as possible. With constantly spawning reinforcements.

This game is obviously not for everybody, whether you'll enjoy the experience or not will depend on your expectations and attitude towards it, if you like games like Hotline Miami, and/or are a completionist, SUPERHOT is definitely a good pick for you. And if your satisfaction of hitting insane shots, slicing through dudes with a katana and watching the real time replays of your slow motion killing sprees barely drops after thousands of kills, you'll know you have received the signal.

reviewText:
SUPERHOT IS THE MOST INNOVATIVE SHOOTER I'VE PLAYED IN YEARS!

In all seriousness, SUPERHOT really is a fresh take on shooters, it is great for people who can appreciate a game for it's enjoyable mechanics and gameplay, and don't need a fully fledged story and GPU taxing graphics (although the story/lore is spread throughout the whole game, including secrets, minigames and the likes, and the purposely simplistic look is still quite aesthetically pleasing).

You don't beat the game when you're finished with story mode, it's more of an primer to the arena and challenge modes, the latter of which take the story levels for a spin and introduce new features and limitations, forcing you to change up your playstyle. The Endless aka the arena mode is just killing red guys. As many as possible. With constantly spawning reinforcements.

This game is obviously not for everybody, whether you'll enjoy the experience or not will depend on your expectations and attitude towards it, if you like games like Hotline Miami, and/or are a completionist, SUPERHOT is definitely a good pick for you. And if your satisfaction of hitting insane shots, slicing through dudes with a katana and watching the real time replays of your slow motion killing sprees barely drops after thousands of kills, you'll know you have received the signal.

reviewText:
I see SUPERHOT described almost universally as an FPS, and while that's true in a superficial (SUPER. FICIAL.) sort of way, I feel like the best descriptor is 'puzzle game'. I won't go into specifics, because I think it's been well-covered by this point, but SUPERHOT feels and plays like a very tense and methodical puzzle game, constantly throwing you into new and interesting scenarios requiring you to make careful moves using the tools at hand to solve the problem. And you feel like a badass doing it.

Visually, the game is simple, but there's a definite beauty in that simplicity, and it also facilitates the mentally taxing gameplay by making everything immediately visually apparent at all times. Levels are white, enemies are red, guns and objects are black. You're never guessing.

Yes, the campaign is somewhat short, and as levels go, that's really all there is, but those levels are great and varied, and the story is certainly as out there and memorable as the rest of the game's elements. Aside from the campaign, there's an endless mode and many challenges to complete, which consist of the campaign levels remixed with various new rules and conditions, such as using only a katana, or allowing you to kill with single punches and teleport into enemy bodies at will. I can see some feeling as though the challenges add little to the overall package, but I think I've personally had even more fun with most of the levels in the challenge mode than in the main campaign. They are definitely worth playing through even after you complete the story.

For me, this is one of the most unique and memorable games I've played in a while It‚Äôs the most innovative shooter I‚Äôve played in years, and unlike a lot of games, I think I'm going to have a lot of fun going for 100% completion, and all the achievements in this one.

reviewText:
In 2013 the internet was graced with a small prototype FPS called SUPERHOT and it quickly took the web by storm. Many people played through the prototype and found it to be a totally original take on the first person shooter genre, thus wanting more.

Fast forward to today, February 26th 2016, the day that we get the full version of SUPERHOT. In short it‚Äôs a much longer and expanded version of the prototype that has also been given a story. In many ways this helps the game succeed but it does also hurt the game in small ways.

I‚Äôm going to do my best to avoid actually covering the contents of the story, because truthfully the story is great. The story is pretty damn incredible and is told through an interesting way. SUPERHOT‚Äôs main menu actually acts as an operating system, with you the user. In between levels you‚Äôll instant message with your virtual friends about SUPERHOT. It‚Äôs an interesting technique which makes the game, a game within a game. It becomes clear pretty quickly that the game is that much better when played in VR but it‚Äôs not bad at all when played on your computer. The story spans about 2 to 2 and half hours. This length isn‚Äôt bad, I‚Äôd argue it‚Äôs actually the perfect length for this type of game, however SUPERHOT has launched at $25, which is rather pricey for a game of this length.

Once you complete SUPERHOT‚Äôs story you are able to play through Endless mode as well as challenges but whether those two help justify the game‚Äôs price tag is really up to you. Challenges essentially place you in a level but will require you to complete the level in specific ways, for example you are only able to use a katana, etc. It‚Äôs a good addition to the game though it‚Äôs not something I will personally play too frequently. Additionally, endless mode allows you to choose a level and play through until you die, as enemies will never stop spawning. Again, it‚Äôs a fine addition though not particularly my cup of tea. In my opinion the reason to play SUPERHOT is it‚Äôs story and the game play, but the real question you should ask yourself when considering it are whether the amount of time you‚Äôll put into the game is worth your $25.

Enough about the game‚Äôs modes though because what makes SUPERHOT shine is the game play. It‚Äôs incredibly rare that a game launches and brings out a new take on a classic genre, but SUPERHOT is absolutely the game that does this. It puts the FPS genre on its head and it‚Äôs incredibly well done. SUPERHOT is not the best looking game ever. It certainly has its own style and it isn‚Äôt by any means bad looking, but it is somewhat bland. The world is mostly white and gray with all enemies standing out in a bright red color. The game is a first person shooter however the catch is that the world only moves when you do. This creates a really interesting sense of game play where you can literally run through clouds of bullets and catch the enemies‚Äô guns midair while also giving yourself time to think about how to proceed. Though SUPERHOT is 100% a shooter it‚Äôs also very much a puzzle game and you‚Äôll find yourself repeating the same level over and over trying different methods until you find success on the other side. There are a few different weapons from guns like the handgun, shotgun and assault rifle as well as the melee weapons which consist of the katana and your fists. Each level presents something new and the game never ceases to be fun.

Additionally upon completion of a level you will watch a re-run of your successful play through without the slow pauses you‚Äôll make completing the level. It‚Äôs a cool idea because though it may take you a minute or two to play through the level, you can watch what it would then look like in 30 seconds, almost like it would look in a movie. SUPERHOT also allows you to edit or cut down your video and upload it to a website the developers set up called Killstagram.com. This is actually one of my favorite features of the game because it encourages players to get the coolest run they can, and then instantly allows them to share it around the world.

SUPERHOT didn‚Äôt run without issues however. I kept getting hard frame rate drops seemingly out of nowhere. It‚Äôs a strange thing too because I was actually playing the game prior to its official release with no problems, but since the launch day update I‚Äôve had plenty of frame rate issues. I have to assume this will be patched and fixed up real quick but it is another thing to take note of for now.

SUPERHOT is a really fantastic game, and it‚Äôs the kind of game that truly re-defines a gaming genre. It‚Äôs a game that everyone should play at some point in time. At its current price, however, you really need to determine how much money your enjoyment is worth. At 2-2.5 hours for the story that‚Äôs rather pricey in the current gaming age we live in, especially for games on Steam. Now that isn‚Äôt to say the game isn‚Äôt worth it. It‚Äôs an incredible game that packs a lot of fun into a short time. Additionally the current release is available only on Steam (Windows, OSX and Steambox) but it will be coming to consoles soon with the Xbox One first sometime in March 2016.

Overall I think you should definitely play SUPERHOT. It‚Äôs fun and original and well worth your time. The only thing you need to decide is when to buy it.

SUPERHOT gets an 8/10

reviewText: SUPERHOT is your fantasies of being in an action movie realized. The time slow mechanic lets you calculate your next action, aim at a target, or appreciate the really cool lighting effects, to reinforce the action movie feel. Secondly, if you don't dodge the bullets, you'll die. Third, you have to lead enemies into your bullets if their not standing still, meaning you have to put extra consideration into each shot. The main gripe I hear about this game is that it's too short for the price, but there are tons of extra challenges and an endless mode to extend the life of the game if you like that kind of thing. Otherwise, pick it up on a sale.

reviewText:
The most innovative shooter I've played in years. Seriously.

Pros:
- Unique and incredible gameplay.
- Challenging levels.
- Beautiful graphics, sound and art style.
- Endless mode.

Cons:
- Story a little short.
- A bit too highly priced?

I was one of those people who played the original demo of SUPERHOT when it was a browser game. I loved it and so could not wait to get my hands on a copy when I saw it had been released on Steam, really hoping that it would have the same thrill that it gave me all those years ago.

Oh boy, did it do just that.

SUPERHOT really offers something I've not seen in many other games. I think the thing that shines most from it is the unique gameplay, and how you not only have to think about your movement but also which weapon is suited best at the current time.

As for the story, although a little confusing, I did question what it was really about and after completing the game I am fairly sure that was its intention. I won't reveal much about it as you really have to experience it for yourself and ask your own questions (also the game asks for no reveals).

The graphics, sound and art style are all fantastic and will keep you zoned into the game for hours.

On the down side however, I would have liked the story to be a little longer especially for that asking price. On the plus side though the completition of it unlocks the 'Endless Mode' plus challenges, extending the gameplay.

There are also a few minor bugs, the most notable I found was bullets hitting walls where there were no walls.

That's my view of it, but I highly recommend you check it out for yourself or even just the browser demo if you're not sure. Overall a very stunning game and easily one of my favourites to play.

column35:
but my playstyle consists of using everything available to me. The levels were also probably made with the hotswitch in mind, so I'd be making it needlessly difficult. Furthermore, the time spent on hotswitch could have been spent on another part of the game (e.g. leaderboards, making melee opponents an actual threat).

The review thus far has actually been rather positive. The gameplay is good, the story is so-so but secondary to endless, and I have a few minor complaints. The reason it's negative is because much like other people, I don't believe the price tag is warranted, and it's not because of the short story as I've made clear, but because the endless mode isn't really that compelling (and that's partially why I made those points above, as possible contributing factors as to why). Perhaps part of this is the lack of a feeling of progression. Sure, the number gets bigger, but from what I've seen, endless just continues with the same thing forever. Given the name, that's reasonable, but the enemies' deficiencies become obvious, and the difficulty becomes too much about dealing with mobs of them. Melee enemies are rarely a threat, so the set of weapons I previously said was fine (and still is in the player's hand) is cut down to 3, just the guns (but they have infinite ammo for the enemies). The AI seems to be very basic, and often the game consists of just doing the same strategies in reponse to the same actions. This seems like it will inevitably become monotonus.

A level editor would break up the lack of content and tedium. The slowed gameplay very nicely supports strategy / puzzle type levels, where endless is more luck and figuring out what to do. To actually address my complaints, a massive amount of content would have to be added or changed, which isn't feasible, though I really wonder what this game's budget was to demand $25.

Edit: After playing some more, I'm further convinced the game isn't worth the price tag. Due to the slowed nature of the game, it's not a test of mechanical skills (which isn't bad in itself). It's about tactics and patience. Patience because while you CAN look around while in slow-motion, more often than not, there's nothing there, so it eventually becomes annoying and many deaths are the result of not bothering to look around. Furthermore, every enemy CAN be dodged, even the rifle and shotgun ones. The issue is: it's a lot of work, a lot of zigzagging, and a lot of jumping. So even more deaths are the result of bum rushing them in hopes that you won't have to bother with that. As far as tactics go, it's a very, very simple brand of tactics. You're only ever faced with a small amount of situations, and the response is always fits into a few specific responses. The levels seem increasingly poorly designed, given how easy it is to camp in a corner in most of them, which is easily the most effective strategy in the game because you just have to shoot down a single path and get an infinite supply of ammo from enemies. So, even the gameplay becomes tedious at some point, at least in terms of endless. I'd still be very interested in a level editor.

reviewText:
This key was obtained from evolve.pr for the purposes of review.

Target Audience:   FPS OR Strategy fans that want a unique shooting experience.

Video Review:   https://youtu.be/1GN6AY4hkcY

Summary:
Gets almost everything right. It's not a game that you see everyday, and that's a good thing, because it's a unique experience that you haven't really played before. The slow down mechanic twists the FPS gameplay to be more strategy based, and it's glorious for it. The skill ceiling is high: being able to shoot a guy in the head, throw a gun, take over another body,  grab the same gun, and then shoot someone else in the head: it's a wonderful feeling. Not only does the game mess with mechanics, it messes with your head. The story is a good 4th wall breaking experience, and like to push your buttons: in the best of ways. Honestly, the mechanics are polished so much, and while the game could use more content, it's able to deliver here. It's just the price that will drive people away, and that's a hard sell for 25 bucks. From a shear enjoyment factor, this game is worth the price. But note: some will find it a hard sell at that price, and I can't hold it against those who'd pause on that premise. But never the less, it's one of the most unique experiences I've had in the last 2 years, and that's saying something.

Lists:
+:
Superhot. Superhot. Superhot.
An absolutely fantastic concept executed brilliantly. Something completely different in the FPS genre, and nothing is really like it.
The Endless mode has that old Arcade feeling. Aka, you're ready and willing to start up play again right after the next run, as it's got that addictive factor to it.
Game has a high skill ceiling thanks to the strategy mechanics that can be mastered with its simple detail. Predicting where people are moving and inserting a bullet into their skull is great.
Like a good amount of the challenges. In particular the Katana one, and the one bullet per gun challenge.
The minimalistic aesthetic does wonders for the themes of the game. It still has a visual impact when blowing apart a head or cutting someone in two. Small touches like the glow of spawns helps the gameplay immensely.
Like the story telling here. It breaks the 4th wall, takes the wall, and smacks you over the head with it.
Like the body swapping mechanic. It's a good escape mechanic, but actually has a consequence with forcing the dropping of the weapon. So you have to use it wisely.
The game's menus have an ASCII charm to it that I can't ignore. Love the little mini games, and the little jokes within them. All I could do is smile.
-:
The price tag combined with the content. It's asking way too much for what's here, and while what's here is rather polished, it just doesn't do enough in the big picture.
It could use a little bit more content, even if it could ‚Äúmuddy‚Äù the design waters. More levels would be nice.
The game gets in your head so much, that you wonder what is truth and what is real. Like the referral system.

UPDATE: So Superhot has some problems


Problem 1: In the latest patch they changed the movement speed to what feels almost 2x as fast as it used to be. This makes basic movement and dodging much more difficult and way less satisfying in general. Enemies can now move much more within even a brief key tap. This can be somewhat avoided by using a controller (since you can push the thumbstick forward a tiny amount to move slowly.

Problem 2: What's even worse is that it feels like they increased the time that passes when you turn. In the old version you could do a quick 360 to get some situational awareness and plan your next move, even while being attacked. Now turning even 90 degrees is enough time for a guy to shoot you from halfway across the map it seems. Suspect a guy is behind you? Turning around is enough time for him to kill you, and ignoring him means he will kill you. Tough luck.

The combination of these two changes (mistakes, honestly) ruins the flow of the game. It's more difficult, and while difficult does not = bad it also makes the game less fun, which IS bad. It feels like the only way to get a high score in the endless mode anymore is to hunker down somewhere where the enemies can only come at you from one direction and can't see you until they are close. That's right, they turned a game about acrobatics, style, strategy, and movement into a game about ...camping. Superhot was supposed to be DIFFERENT from normal shooters, and now it just feels more like them, and not in a good way.

Let me show you what I mean:

This first clip was captured by me before the changes

https://killstagram.com/s/QuixoticSociableRazzmatazzIguana

This second clip was also captured by me, on the exact same level, after the changes

https://killstagram.com/s/OnlyCaringFernHorse

See the difference? Running around like in the first clip just isn't possible anymore, or is at least much more difficult to pull off. The amount of time it takes to do anything now, even simply looking around to understand what you're dealing with, is too much time.

Now, I'm not gonna lie: That second clip was still pretty fun.

And that's the thing. After all this, I still can't dislike this game. The 12+ hours I put into it before this patch got me more than my money's worth, and other than these two changes the game is unchanged.

But it isn't as fun as it used to be.

At the moment, I still recommend the game. The idea is fresh, the art fits perfectly, the story is great, the map designs are varied, the challenge modes change the game in neat ways, and the endless mode is a fun way to casually game while listening to a podcast. If you're a new player you probably won't even have any problems with the new changes since you don't know what it was like before.

But for me, THE MOST INNOVATIVE SHOOTER I'VE PLAYED IN YEARS was the old Superhot, not this new one, and I hope they change it back.

reviewText:
If Jason Bourne got trapped in a postmodern painting, this is how it would be.

Graphics are just as refreshing as the trailer promised, with clean fractals and simplistic objects.

Gameplay consists of sequential combat scenarios, each drastically different from the last. Swing swords, throw bottles and pull triggers until your brain breaks from the stress of predicting each enemy's movements over the next three seconds.

The plot is Inception-level confusing, fragmented and suspenseful. Recommended for puzzle junkies and FPS-players alike.

reviewText: SUPERHOT is a game nearly entirely based on its core mechanic: time moves only when you do. When this mechanic is placed in the context of an FPS game, you essentially transform it from an action game into a puzzle game as you carefully weave through a barrage of gun fire, looking for a way to dispatch an enemy from afar. Replays occur in realtime, lending to a feeling of OP badassery.\n\nThere's some question of whether this game is worth its price point and I honestly suspect that is going to be highly user-dependent. Are you into speedruns and doing weird cost-effectiveness calculations in your head? Then you'll probably find it worthwhile. Otherwise, you might want to hold off a bit or find a friend with a discount code.

reviewText:
It's the most innovative shooter I've played in years!

SUPERHOT is an awesome game with an unique mechanism, the time moves only when you move; the game is precise and every steps can be crucial. Most negative reviews are against the price of the game since you can beat the story mode in easily 2 hours (It have 33 stages, but if you want to do some cool replays you will probably take 5+ hours to beat the game).

People shouldn't complain since you are here for the gameplay and not the plot. Once you beat the game you unlock the challenges modes which gives an excellent replayability to the title. (Katana only, Barehanded, Speedrun, Ghost and a few more) even the game's menu is unique.

Pros:
-SUPERHOT
-AWESOME GAMEPLAY
-The improved HOTSWITCH feature
-Stages are unique and have an awesome aspect
-The secrets are so well hidden, sometimes they're literally under the map
-Challenge modes
-Endless mode
-Polygon graphics
-GLASS DUDES are so aesthethic
-Free DLC's confirmed

Cons:
-Short story
-No workshop or mod support
-Replays are in 480p
-Where are the mods/cheats from the beta?

reviewText:
While many people praise Superhot for its unique bullet-time element (which, of course, is entirely correct), it should also be noted that its level design is simply incredibly well-thought out as there is always a perfect balance between cover and available items to defend yourself.

In short:

+ Highly intuitive, and unique bullet-time concept
+ Well-optimised, runs like a horse (on PC - Windows)
+ Interesting narrative with a story to be followed
+ Nice abstract design that feels comfortable

- Expensive
- Too short, lack of content. Additional modes are padding content
- Rarely you'll feel confused by the system that sometimes just kills you without any reason (for instance bullet that's far away still hitting you)

I can only recommend SUPERHOT, but I can't hide the fact that's it's expensive, so for those with a little patience are better off waiting for a sale, at which it will be completely worth the purchase.

reviewText:
A breath of fresh air for FPS.
I have been following this game for some time, since it was first shown as a Game Jam '14 entry. Instantly I thought it looked very interesting and fun. Now that the game is released and modestly fleshed out, I have to admit, I LOVE it!!

So the main mechanic is the speed of time. When you are not moving, it moves SUPER slow. When you look around, it speeds up a little. Finally, when you move, it goes into normal speed. Your object is to kill the enemies utilising these mechanics without eating a bullet, fist or blade first. It sounds simple but it is almost like a puzzle game at times when you need to figure out the order of your actions otherwise you die. You can punch dudes, grab their guns and shoot them in the head and then throw the empty gun at someone to stun them, allowing you to move in for the kill. It's great fun and SUPER satisfying.

The story" is not too long and seems to be the main complaint amongst folk. Depending on your skill level

People shouldn't complain since you are here for the gameplay and not the plot. Once you beat the game you unlock the challenges modes which gives an excellent replayability to the title. (Katana only, Barehanded, Speedrun, Ghost and a few more) even the game's menu is unique.

Pros:
-SUPERHOT
-AWESOME GAMEPLAY
-The improved HOTSWITCH feature
-Stages are unique and have an awesome aspect
-The secrets are so well hidden, sometimes they're literally under the map
-Challenge modes
-Endless mode
-Polygon graphics
-GLASS DUDES are so aesthethic
-Free DLC's confirmed

Cons:
-Short story
-No workshop or mod support
-Replays are in 480p
-Where are the mods/cheats from the beta?

reviewText:
SUPERHOT is a beautifully executed shooter with an intriguing and novel catch.

The game is fantastic, but it ends too quickly and gets old pretty fast. It's not worth the full price, buy it at $10 or lower.

I hope they'll do free expansions, since it was way too little for the price of admission.

reviewText:
I want to recommend this game.

Superhot is an FPS with an interesting and unique premise and that's that time moves when you move. The claim here, however, is false. When one here decides they wish to stop in the face bullets, these bullets continue to move. Men with guns will continue to aim, and brutes oozing to bruise will still turning around after you've decided to jump over them, but very very slowly. So it is then needed to predict not only where everything will end up once time flows normally, but also weither these minor changes will affect your next action.
This is inline with the biggest part of the game, which is mental eyeballing of distances of bullets relative to your exterior. An exterior that you don't know the limits of, however. There's no way to judge your own hitbox, other than the idea that if it's not under you or towards the center of your view then you're probably safe, but this is not always the case. This might not seem important, I mean most FPS don't have or need full body awareness, but this game is about Spacial Awareness and I am not aware of my own space. Not to mention most other games I can tank a bullet.
One hit kill games need to stop, just saying. Being a slow time badass isn't that fun when in psuedo-stopped time that's a bullet in your face with nothing you can do about it and the grim reapear laughing in your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.
The deceivingly simple and pretty graphics of the game are amazing, although due to preformance issues I have must feel that something is very taxing in this area. Lastly, the worst thing, and the most deal breaking problem with the entire game is the sound design. There is no music. Straight up, nothing. With some sort of system that either had a time slowed to time not slowed fade in, or a song that sounded good but sped up and slow, this would've been godly. Sadly though without music at times everything feels same-ish and rather tedious as the game occupies only one sense.

Pros:
-Unique
-Pretty
-Feel like a badass

Cons:
-Preformance Issues
-Short af
-No music
-Not actual stopped time

Is it worth 25 dollars, no, not at all. The max I would pay for this is 10 dollars, if even.

(And yes, I'm old enough to get what they're doing with the interface, that doesn't make it good.) Perhaps the most bizarre thing about it is that the entire, Time only moves when you move
date: Premise isn't even true. Time just moves very slowly when you're not moving and the game is worse for this fact. It's pretty and performs respectably but that's about the best I can say for Superhot. To say it's not worth it would be an understatement. Hopefully some post-launch support will bring this up to snuff but for right now it's a game with an ingenious idea but very botched execution and not nearly enough content for the asking price.

reviewText:
I want to recommend this game.

Superhot is an FPS with an interesting and unique premise and that's that time moves when you move. The claim here, however, is false. When one here decides they wish to stop in the face bullets, these bullets continue to move. Men with guns will continue to aim, and brutes oozing to bruise will still turning around after you've decided to jump over them, but very very slowly. So it is then needed to predict not only where everything will end up once time flows normally, but also weither these minor changes will affect your next action.
This is inline with the biggest part of the game, which is mental eyeballing of distances of bullets relative to your exterior. An exterior that you don't know the limits of, however. There's no way to judge your own hitbox, other than the idea that if it's not under you or towards the center of your view then you're probably safe, but this is not always the case. This might not seem important, I mean most FPS don't have or need full body awareness, but this game is about Spacial Awareness and I am not aware of my own space. Not to mention most other games I can tank a bullet.
One hit kill games need to stop, just saying. Being a slow time badass isn't that fun when in psuedo-stopped time that's a bullet in your face with nothing you can do about it and the grim reapear laughing in your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.
The deceivingly simple and pretty graphics of the game are amazing, although due to preformance issues I have must feel that something is very taxing in this area. Lastly, the worst thing, and the most deal breaking problem with the entire game is the sound design. There is no music. Straight up, nothing. With some sort of system that either had a time slowed to time not slowed fade in, or a song that sounded good but sped up and slow, this would've been godly. Sadly though without music at times everything feels same-ish and rather tedious as the game occupies only one sense.

Pros:
-Unique
-Pretty
-Feel like a badass

Cons:
-Preformance Issues
-Short af
-No music
-Not actual stopped time

Is it worth 25 dollars, no, not at all. The max I would pay for this is 10 dollars, if even.

reviewText:
Two things you need to know about before jumping in:
1) This game is very short. I completed the story mode in 1 hr and 30 mins. It may take longer for those who are having trouble but either way, it is a short experience.

2) It's asking price is a little high for what you get. I don't think the game is worth the $22 I paid for it but if you were to pick this game up at say $15-$10, do it.

With that said, SuperHot is a very enjoyable fps that makes the player conduct each mission as if it were a puzzle. You can't approach this game like a run and gun shooter and it may take you a few deaths in order to come up with a strategy. Again, if it goes on sale pick this game up. It is a great game but not a good value.
